bibdata.title: Require rubygems/package to fix cache_file rake task

comments.body: What happens now if the transfer fails? Will it re-process the SCSB file?
@tpendragon The error should cause the dumpfile / boundwiths-file processing jobs to restart and re-proccess the file.
@eliotjordan And that's safe?

@tpendragon The original dump file is never altered. The processed file is saved as a tempfile and sent to S3. That was happening before this PR. If the transfer fails, the only penalty should be the extra time to run the job again. It was the way to get these to be idempotent.

bibdata.title: Incremental recap dump files are not uploaded to S3

dpul.title: [DPUL/production] ActionView::Template::Error: Please use symbols for polymorphic route arguments.

comments.body: @dependabot rebase

dpul.title: As a site builder, I would like to be able to include side search refining facets for item level metadata included in the "more information" slide for each item.
As a user, when I search for content in the scope notes of the MVWs for Grounds and buildings and Historic Postcards, I do not find everything I know to be there or I find nothing at all

comments.body: Phoebe kindly supplied a document for us! https://docs.google.com/document/d/16Ah0yDuNBQSo3Bjn6GxBr2dkhb7ZqiMe7B73ZvcAMFw/edit?ts=60a52460
I suspect the problem here is that the metadata from the child volumes of MVWs isn't indexed (and I notice the value in question here is in the `description` field, not in the `metadata` hash).
So would this be a "add the metadata for description elsewhere" issue, or is this something that would be solved with indexing? I would not think so?

an interesting elaboration from stakeholders: _the one thing I would clarify is that I think DPUL *is* searching the item-level metadata in Postcards more consistently, or at least I did not run into the search issues in Postcards that I did with Grounds._
might be worth comparing fields used between the two?
Yes, I think this can likely be fixed with indexing, particularly if the issue is that MVW volume metadata is being indexed, but just not the `description` field for whatever reason.

I looked for an example in the historical postcards, and noticed the word "undivided" in the item metadata for one of the Art Museum postcards. Searching for "undivided" retrieved the Art Museum postcard object (https://dpul.princeton.edu/catalog/9g54xt090). Looking at the metadata, I see that text in the metadata hash under the "abstract" field, instead of the top-level `description` field. So updating the indexing to also index the `description` field would probably fix this. Though we could also just decide to use `abstract` instead, and these would work as-is.

I don't have permission to that document. I can't really dig into this right now, but for reference we only index the metadata hash in the IIIF document if the JSON-LD seeAlso isn't present. So for the postcard example https://figgy.princeton.edu/catalog/c013ae22-efa4-4af1-9072-fc460786aaea.jsonld is what we index.

Ideally, standardizing the field used  would be the best way forward (i.e. using the abstract field in lieu of description), especially considering we may have more of these FA with item level descriptions in need of homes (like MC085).  Can you see any downside to this?
@tpendragon just changed permissions: https://docs.google.com/document/d/16Ah0yDuNBQSo3Bjn6GxBr2dkhb7ZqiMe7B73ZvcAMFw/edit?usp=sharing

More reference to help figure this issue out:

The individual postcard that returned in @escowles' test comes back because it's indexed and hidden by DPUL in searches, so that its parent returns for any matches it hits: https://dpul.princeton.edu/catalog/tm70mv28c

The example in the document provided (https://figgy.princeton.edu/catalog/348a2c23-6e47-4521-b6b6-9eb3153e2083) isn't indexed in DPUL by itself: https://dpul.princeton.edu/catalog/5h73pw68z
